div.p:
The First Negroes in Florida,Perhaps the earliest mention of
a Negro in Florida occurs in the account of the expedition of Narvaes
in 1528. It will be recalled that after the ruin of that expedition
Cabeza de Vaca and three companies reached Mexico after almost six
years of incredible suffering. According to De Vaca's account, one
of his companions was Esteban, a blackamoor from Asomeur on the west
coast of Morocco, who was the slave of Dorantes, capatain of infantry
in Narvaes' army.

This same Negro was the guide of Fray Marcos de Nisa in 1539, and
was sent ahead of the Corenado expedition to report the character of
the country. Esteban's experience with Indians and his natural dramatic
instinct led him to plan an impressive entrance into the new regions,
but he knew Fray Marcos would not approve. Accordingly, he persuaded
the priest to allow him to travel two days in advance, and a strange
procession went forward: Esteban, borne like Indian royalty on a cano-
pied seat and accompanied by hundreds of male and female attendants,
while after him plodded Fray Marcos, afoot, with only a small native
guard. All went well until Esteban reached the country of the Yunis,
who refused to be awed and fell upon him and killed him. Fray Marcos
escaped a similar fate by presenting trinkets to the Indians.

With slavery a widespread institution in Europe, it was natural
that slaves were used in developing the New World. There were some
Negro slaves with John Harkins when he stopped at Fort Caroline on the
St. Johns River in 1565. He had sold most of his slaves to Spaniards
in the West Indies, but one Negro was reported lost on the shore in
front of Fort Caroline, and was believed to have been eaten by an al-
ligator. It is not improbable, however, that he escaped and sought
refuge among the Indians, as so many of his race did later.

There were Negro slaves in St. Augustine, probably from the very
first, but their number was negligible. Negro slaves of the Spanish
King were sent to Florida in 1581, and a small party of them were
employed for two years in making wooden platforms for the artillery of
the old fort at St. Augustine. There is also a record of a Negro slave
at the St. Augustine friary in 1569. In 1594 the Governor of Florida
asked the Governor of Cuba for a number of soldiers and a "few slaves."
In the first hospital in the United States, built at St. Augustine in
1597, a Negroess in the royal service tended "soldiers, Indian, and
Negroes." In 1603 there were 32 Negro slaves in St. Augustine, five
of whom were women. It is likely that these Negro slaves were servants,
as the Spanish enslaved Indians for hard labor.

However, the Indians reacted so unsatisfactorily to strenuous manual
labor that the arrival of Negro slaves for field work was hailed with
joy. A shout went up as the ship of Don Juan de Aila came to another in
the harbor of St. Agustine in 1687, a shout that was the beginning of
a celebration lasting all day. For, on the ship of the Don, in addition
to the usual cargo, was a black slave, the one survivor of the 12 that
the Spaniard had put on board.

To the Spanish colonists of new Florida the slave came to mean
food--someone to raise crops on the farms near St. Augustine. The
new slave had companions because the Spaniards were strict; in
addition to other qualifications, a slave was required to become a
Catholic before being brought into Florida.

The slave of Don Juan was not long to remain alone; in the years
that immediately followed he was joined, at St. Augustine and other
parts of the region, by numbers of other Negroes who sought the col-
onists of the Carolinas.

It was during this period of the first Spanish occupation of
Florida that the connection between the Negro and the Indian first
occurred. Indians were if the Creek and Yamaneo tribes, who occupied
a wide territory in what was later to be Georgia. Both Indians and
Negroes frequently escaped from their masters in Carolina, and made
their way southward to the Spanish territory of Florida. Here the
Spaniards erected a fort for the refugees, a few miles north of their
own San Marcos. This fort, called Fort Moosa,was built between 1687
and 1695; it consisted of a large square with breastwork and four
bastions. In and near this fort a larger group of Negroes lived in
comparative freedom.

The constant escape of Negro and Indian slaves from Carolina to
Florida contributed to the creation of the Georgia colony. In Georgia,
ownership of slaves was at first forbidden, as it was believed that
a free state between Florida and Carolina would greatly reduce the
number of escapes. After eight years, the need for Negro labor ended
the free status of Georgia.

By June of 1740, the number of Negroes occupying Fort Moosa had
become a factor in the threatening hostilities between the Spaniards
and Governor James Oglethorpe of Georgia. Learning that the Englishman
planned an attack, the Spanish governor, Montiano, strengthened both
forts Moosa and San Marcos. A band of 80 Scotch Highlnders, however,
captured Fort Moosa in the early days of the Oglethorpe invasion of
St. Augustine, and it was later retaken only after several hundred
Spaniards and Negroes had been hurled against it. In this engagement,
the English leader, Colonel Palmer, was killed, and many of his men
were captured and imprisoned in the St. Augustine fort.

The Seminole Increases. The infiltration of Georgia Indians into
Florida greatly increased about 1750 when a chieftain of the Creek in
Gerogia, Seacoffee, left the Creek tribes and moved into Florida with
a large following. They mingled with both Negroes and the Miccosukee
Indians who had preceded tham, and enjoyed many of the privileges of
free Spanish citizenship. Gradually the Indian tribes in Florida
became known as Seminole, meaning separatists or runaways.

When Georgia became a slave-holding province, the number of Indians
and Negro runaways in Florida increased rapidly, to the extent, finally,
that in 1776 the Council for Safety of Georgia requested from Congress
a large force of troops "to prevent their slaves from deserting their
Masters."

About this date it became known that Indians and Negro runaways
had settled in numbers around the Suwannee and Apalachicola Rivers, in
addition to the settlements they already had in eastern and central
Florida. This brief prosperity that the Negroes and Seminole enjoyed--
the last in their history--was made possible by the war between England
and the American colonies, the largely unexplored condition of Florida
as a whole, and the fact that within the Carolina, North Georgia, and
Florida boundaries there were still savage tribes of Creek Indians to
be encountered.

The first serious threat to this breathing-spell came in 1783,
when, at the close of the Revolutionary War, the Creek of Georgia made
a treaty with the authorities of the state, in which they promised to
restore all slaves residing among them. While the authenticity of this
treaty was disputed, it was to have a profound effect upon the fate of
the escaped Negroes and Seminole in Florida.

The Second Spanish Period. The Second Spanish period was one of
--> significant developments for Negroes. Although the British, departing
from Florida after the American Revolution, took their slaves with them
many more were brought in by planters who moved to Florida to take up
Spanish grants. These adventurers from the new United States imported
slaves direct from Africa, a practice forbidden in the >United States
after 1808, but countenanced in Florida by Spanish law. As a result,
slaves were brought to Florida in great numbers. The majority of them
were then smuggled across the American border into Georgia and other
states. Their value soared as cotton plantation spread over the
lower South.

Toward the Indians and their Negro allies the Spanish governors
were not as liberal as in former years. The Seminole had never been
Spanish adherents, and the Gerogia Creek Began a series of raids into
Florida, burning villages and taking prisoners.

The first treaty made under the Constitution of the United States
was in reference to Negroes involved in these border events. In a con-
cession of certain lands to the Georgia Creek, a repetition was made of
the stipulation that Negroes were to be surrendered by the Indians.
This provision set the Creek to invading Florida so that they might have
Negro captives to surrender. The treaty bore the date of August 1, 1790,
and the signature of President George Washington.

The succeeding quarter of a century witnessed two interesting
developments for the Negroes of West Florida and their Indian allies:
an intensification of the efforts of the officials of slaveholding
Georgia to reclaim the growing number of free Negroes in Florida, and
the tighter cementing of the bonds between Negroes and Seminole. The
Indians and Negroes in 1812 defeated an army raised by Georgia which had
penetrated about a hundred miles into Florida; they cut it off from its
supplies, and sent it back nearly starved. In 1811 the Governor of
Georgia ordered the formation of an army large enough "to reduce
St. Augustine and punish the Indians."

It was not in the East Florida section around St. Augustine,
however, that the Negroes suffered their first major disaster. An
expedition did enter that section of the state during the Republic of
Florida rebellion, but after two years returned to Georgia with little
but casualties to show for its efforts.

In 1814 several British vessels assisted the Negroes and Seminole
in the area around the Apelachicola River to erect a fort, stock it
with ammunition, and mount it with eight guns. This fort was about
thirty miles above the mouth of the river, on its east bank. The fort
was generally called the Negro Fort, but its official name was Fort
Blount. That the Negroes and their Seminole friends believed in the
security of the fort seems evident from the fact that many farms and
plantations sprang up in the vicinity; one historian says cultivated
feields extended more than fifty miles along the river. There were
hundreds of Negroes and Seminole in the area, and they owned large
herds of cattle and horses.

On the morning of July 24, 1816, the quiet of the fort was shat-
tered by the booming of the two 18-pound guns; General Andrew Jackson, in
charge of the southern forces of the United States Army, had ordered
Colonel Clinch and Captain Loomis to attack the fort, "blow it up, and
return the niggers to their rightful owners."

After four days of attack from both land and water, a heated
cannonball pierced a powder magazine incide the stockade, and all
but 60 of the 334 persons inside the fort were instantly killed. Only
three escaped injury. Two of the survivors, one Indian and one Negro,
were executed as "leaders."

hi.label:
Chapter II
Florida Ceded to the United States

div.p:
On July 10, 1821, the Negroes in Florida saw the American flag
raised over the Territory. It meant the enslavement of every Negro
who could be captured. Under Spanish law a slave could file a petition
for a new master, while under American law his testimony was not al-
lowed in court. The Seminole also viewed Americans with disfavor, hav-
ing fought as English allies against them in the Revolution. So the
reaction of the Seminole and the Negroes associated with them was to
retire deeper into the fastnesses of the Florida swamps and forests,
and to resist the American forces in what were to become famous as the
Seminole Wars.

Seminole Wars. From the destruction of Fort Blount in 1816, until
1842, the Seminole Wars were waged intermittantly. Actually, there had
been no peace between the Seminole and their Negro allies on the one
hand and the American forces on the other since the destruction of Fort
Blount. General Jackson, with four thousand regular and volunteer
troops, had already defeated Negroes in several towns around Lake
Miccosukee, the Seminole in St. Marks on the Gulf, and combines Sem-
inole and Negro forces along the Suwannee. Those who were not killed
or captured fled to the Everglades.

On Auguat 14, 1842, General J.W. Worth issued an official order
that "hostilities with the Indians within these territories have
ceased." The intervening 26 years had seen the question of surrender-
ing the Negroes cause the postponement of peace with the Seminole many
times; had seen the same question become a major issue first among army
officials; then in the houses of Congress, and finally assist in the
unloading of an attorney-general and the discomfiture of presidents Van
Buren and Tayler.

The campaigne of the Seminole Wars made many historic figures
among whites, Negroes and Indians alike. Because of the enslavement of
Morning Dew, his Creek-Negro wife, the embittered young warrior Osceola
became one of the most feared leaders of the Seminole. Coaccochee and
his inseparable friend Louis--a forment Negro slave who led Major Dade's
army detachment into ambush rather than assist in an attack on the Ne-
groes and Seminole--grew so terrible in legend that there was wide-
spread relief when they agreed to depart from Florida to the west.
Micanopy, with his Negro Abraham--who twice interpreted governmental
treaties so well that clauses objectionable to the Indians had to be
removed-- these and many others crosses Florida's history during the
turbulent years of the Seminole Wars. For years after the close of the
Seminole War, scattered Indians and their Negroes, usually called Maroons,
were a source of concern to the settlers.

Maroons were those Negroes, living among the Seminole, who were
descendants of runaway slaves, and yet had never themselves belonged
to a white man. Proof of their descent usually consisted in demon-
stration of their ability to speak the Seminole language. The United
States Government finally decided that Maroons might emigrate, and
about four hundred of them went west with the Seminole.

Capture of the Last Indian on Amelia Island. Morris Drummond,
Negro resident of Amelia Island near the northeasten border of Flor-
ida, gave the following account of the capture of the last Indian
there: "You want to hear how dey ketch de las Indian on dis hyear is-
land? My granpaw say dey keep a-noticin someun in de cawn patch--de
cawn was broke off, an trompled. Marse Harrison say, 'someun stealin
my cawn, an I blieve it de Indians.'

"Dey notice dat dar ony one set of tranks, but dey know how tricky
dem Indians is. Missis, dey mought be forty or fifty of dem critters,
but dey wouldon lebe but one set of tracks--one ud dem Indians, not
knowin how many dey be. So Marse Harrison plan dat de whole bunch of
buck niggahs surroun dat cawn fiel, an wait. Ifen dey be's a lot of
Indian, we all gwine run; if dey be one or two, we gwine ketch em.
Tareckly dark come outa de woods, widdout no sound come one Indian, an
he warn't too big/ He creep inta de cawn patch an start breakin off de
cawn. Den we all rush im. We ain fraid of one Indian. Dey took dat
Indian an take im ta de plantation, an keep im dar under guard til de
officer come an git im an take im ta de Indian Reservation. An dat was
de las Indian ever seed on de Island of Amelia."

hi.label:
Chapter III
Slave Days in Florida

div.p:
By the turn of the ninteenth century the number of Negro slaves
in the state, as compared to those in neighboring states, was still
small. For the most part they were runaways from the United States
who had been accepted by the Seminole. There were some hundreds in
and around St. Augustine, and a few at St. Marks, Pensacola, and other
smaller communities. In most cases they paid a tribute of farm produce
to the Indians, under a system similar to both medieval surfdom and
modern share-cropping. With none of the stringent bondage of Georgia
and the Carolinas, the Negroes had their own towns and live stock, and
led an unsupervised existence.

Though the number of slaves in Florida grew slowly, they increased
by leaps and bounds in Georgia. Originally settled in 1738 as a buffer
free state between the slave-holding Carolinas and semi-free Florida,
Georgia lost little time in becoming a slave state when the huge planta-
tions, with their need for hundreds of slaves, pushed steadily towards
the Florida border.

The transfer of Florida from Spain to America early in the nine-
teenth century heralded the approach of slave-holding on a large scale.
Agricultural expansion began; plantations appeared on the Apelachicola,
Suwannee,
and St. Johns,
Rivers, and the section around St. Augustine,
.

Classification of Slaves. With few exceptions, the slaves of
Florida fell into one of the two major classifications: farm workers, who
constituted the vast majority, and house slaves, the few lucky men
and women who tended the grounds and homes of their masters. Both men
and women worked in the fields, raising cotton, tobacco, and food crops.
There were a few mechanics, blacksmiths, carpenters, and workers skilled
in other crafts, who were, chiefly confined to the larger plantations.

The Larger Plantations. Among the larger slaveholders was
Zephaniah Kingsley on Fort George Island, near the mouth of the St.
Johns Rivers. Kingsley was concerned with slaves in a number of ways.
He brought them from Africa in his own ships, worked them on his
plantation, and trained them for sale in the slave markets. This
training was many-sided; suffice it to say that at the sales in the
vicinity there were usually offered a number of slaves who were
described as "Kingsley's niggers," who brought more per head than the
others, because of their special training as either house or field
hands. Kingsley's slaves belonged to no unscrupulous pirate dealing
in human flesh. Though he was a professional slavedealer, he had un-
usual standards. At the height of his slave trade he wrote a book,
The Patriarchal System of Society, concerning the merits of slave-
holding as a means of disseminating certain benefits to heathens.
Kingsley married a Negro woman, stating in his will that he respected
fully the African rites that had united them. He provided liberally
for his mulatto descendants.

In the vicinity of Jacksonville, Mandarin, and St. Augustine
there were large plantations, and also public markets where slave
sales were held regularly. In West Florida, particularly in Columbia,
Madison, and Jackson counties, plantations were large than those in
East Florida. In Pensacola there were dozens of liberated and semi-
free slaves working on government forts and properties.

One of the larget plantation in West Florida was El Destino,
settled in 1826. Cotton was the chief product of cultivation, and
corn, oats, sugar cane, potatoes and rice were also grown; in fact,
the aim was to make the plantation self-sufficient. Relations between
master and slaves on this plantation were relatively commandable. Few
changes of ownership occurred, as testified by the appearance of the
same names in the tabulations and reports of the plantation for about
thirty years. Even the War between the States brought only a slight
change among the hands, due to the fact that middle Florida was never
occupied by Federal troops. After the war, many of the ex-slaves
remained to work the old fields on a share-crop basis. In 1919 the
El Destino plantation was sold by descendants of the original owner
for $70,000. It is 17 miles east of Tallahasse, and its magnificent
oaks and shrubbery attract frequent visitors. It is now the property
of Whitehouse of New York City.

The Hanson plantation near St. Augustine raised sugar cane, veg-
etables and fruits. It occupied the exact site of the present Florida
Normal and Industrial Institute, one of the outstanding Negro colleges
in the state. What are now Jefferson and Leon counties, and other sec-
tions of the cotton-and-tabacco belt, had their large plantations, and
there were others farther west and south.

Slave Diets. While the food of the slaves seems to have been about
the same on most plantations, the conditions under which it was eaten
varied greatly. Some former slaves state that when the work signal
sounded in the morning they had to "Git it an run," that is, snatch up
a sandwich or chunk of bread they had prepared the night before and eat
it on the way to the field or after arriving there. Others were allowed
adequate time for breakfast.

Lunch on some plantations was eaten in the field in the greatest
possible haste; on others, lunch time meant a rest period of varying
length for the slave who could eat rapidly.

Supper was the slave's important meal. This was always eaten in
his cabin, with whatever family he might be fortunate enough to have.
It was cooked by his wife or mother, after her own duties were finished
in the field or at the Missus' house. The children, tended during the
day by a Negro woman, shared supper with their parents. Supper usually
consisted of some kind of meat--often only salt pork--green vegetables,
potatoes, corn bread, and coffee or some substitute. The most common
substitute for coffee was corn or corn meal, parched until dark brown,
then boiled. When this was not available, okra seeds and even
parched potatoes were used.

The corn meal was cooked into either pones or pan bread. Corn
bread was sometimes baked in the top of an iron spider, a large pan
wit a compartment in which coals were heaped. Potatoes were wrapped
in the large leaves of the tannion plant, or sometimes in green corn
shucks, and roasted in live coals. Green corn was an occasional and
welcomed treat.

While these were the rations that the master provided and knew
about, other items were consumed that did not so readily come to his
attention. Among these was the wild squash, which grew in the woods
of west Florida. Slave owners had little objection to its use by
slaves, except that a trip to the woods was required to procure it,
involving the possibility of escape.

Pilfered eggs were another common dish. Where stumps and under-
brush were burned to clear the land, the ground beneath the fire would
hold an intense heat. Eggs stolen from nests would be surreptitiously
buried near the fire; a few minutes later a loud crack would inform the
slave that his baked egg also ready to eat. Potatoes, when not included
in the regular fare, were also stolen and cooked in this manner. On
large plantations the problem of feeding all of the Negro children was some-
times solved by "toting" milk to a long wooden trough, tossing in corn
bread and other morsels, and letting the children line up with their
spoons.

Sundays and special occasions would bring dessert as an addition
to the slave's meal. This would sometimes be potato bread made of
sweet potatoes boiled until soft, then mashed, combined with the grease and
coal meal, and baked till brown. None of the Florida ex-slaves reports
the use of sugar in their cabins; when sweetening of any kind was af-
forded, it was sugar-cane molasses.

The amount of meat eaten depended entirely upon the master; it was
not considered a necessary part of a slave's diet. Some plantations
provided it at least once a day, and kept well-filled storehouses.
Others parceled it out very seldom, and then only the unused parts of
the hogs or cows killed for the master's use. Frequent "disappearance"
of hogs was a consequence.

One commodity, salt, seems to have given both master and slave
great cause for worry; the master, because of the expense and trouble
often necessary to secure it, and the slave because he so frequently
went without it. In many cases it was obtained from boiled sea-water;
one plantation owner near Monticello took a team and slave and traveled
40 miles to the Gulf of Mexico, and there boiled down a supply. The
process was slow and laborious.

The slaves had other methods of obtaining it. On some plantations
they would scrape the floor of the smokehouse at every opportunity.
One slave would wash the smokehouse floor, carefully saving the scrub-
water; with this brine she would do her seasoning. Another slave
remembers chopping un a board from the smokehouse floor, and using the
wood chips for seasoning. The wood, soaked with the meat-drippings, im-
parted a flavor of both meat and salt.

Scraps of fat or drops of grease were seldom wasted. Grease
from the "big house" and cabin alike was carefully kept in a special
container.

Soap, Candles, and Cowhide. Oak or cypress wood was burned and
the ashes placed in a vat or tub. The ashes were soaked in water for
several days, and the water then drawn off into a pot. In this pot
was placed the accumulated grease, and the whole mixture boiled for
several hours. The potash and grease mixture was then poured out to
cool, after which it was cut into squares. The plantation then had its
supply of soap.

Beef tallow, melter and poured into moulds, provided light for
the plantation. Some of the slaves were adept at placing strings in
the hardening tallow in such a manner that creditable candles would
result. On many plantations, only the master's house used the candles;
the Negro cabins were illumnated by fireplace.

Oak wood was also used when leather was to be tanned. Oak chips
or ashes would be soaked in water, as in potash making, and when that
solution reached a certain strength cowhides were placed in it. After
a few days the hides were taken out and dried, and later fashioned into
shoes, harnesses, and other articles.

Clothing. Both mistress and maid during Florida's slave period
had a taste for gay color in dress. Cloth was made on many plantations
by the women with the help of those children too young to work in the fields.

White cotton cloth was dyed in a number of ways. The indigo
plant--once grown in Florida commercially and still found in a wild
state--provided blue coloring, and the pokeberry gave a desirable red.
Oak bark provided varying shades of brown, and the walnut an inerad-
icable dark brown.

On some plantations the owners gave the Negro women a white cotton
dress once or twice a year, which was dyed to afford a gay change of
dress for "Sunday-go-to-meetin."

The daily attire of the slaves was not generally colorful; the
men wore coarse pants and shirt, and the women wore tight bodices and
full gathered skirts. These were the days of half a dozen petticoats.
Occasionally a slave became the proud possessor of her mistress' dis-
carded hoop skirt, but this was unusual. Hoops were expensive, so
grape vines and bamboo often served as hoops for both mistress and
slaves.

Amusements. Plantation life was not always all work and no play.
There were definite occasions for merriment and even celebrations on
many plantations; these ran from the usual visits of individuals or
small groups to occasional festivals. Thomas and Bryant Folsom, in
Jefferson County, often stages rival parties to see which could give
his slaves the better times. There were others who let their slaves
go to other plantations for affairs at certain times.

Christmas was the lost popular of these occasions. On some
plantations there were parties with extra food and meat allotments
from the master's house, and other presents for the slaves. Few ex-
slaves remember ever having been overlooked when it came to Christmas
presents. The men usually recieved new shoes or srticles of clothing,
while the women were made happy with household articles or discarded
dresses of the mistress. Several plantations gave their slaves cash
presents.

New Year brought a short day in the field or a holiday, and anoth-
er gift of extra food, with the highly prised meat allotment. New
Year's night, on some plantations, was spent singing, dancing and visiting.

The harvesting of a crop, such as tabacco, cotton or sugarcane,
was cause for celebration also. In at least a few cases there were
celebrations that corresponded very closely to the Green Corn Dance of
the Seminole, though just how much the Seminole dance influenced the
slaves is uncertain.

Occasionally, visits to neighboring plantations would be made
on a large scale. These would bring forth carefully hoarded stores
of molasses, meal, potatoes and other foods; if there was music on
improvised banjos and much jollity, the master might even contribute
a few delicacies for the entertainment of the visitors. Singing and
dancing around a fire in front of one of the cabins would last late
inbto the night and any previously missed opportunities for courting
were eagerly seized by the younger couples. Young husbands and wives,
living apart, made the most of these occasions.

Marriage, Religion, and Baptism. Some plantation owners not only per-
mitted but enouraged the marriage of their slaves. Then both parties
lived on the same plantation, they might be given both legal and rel-
gious ceremony to seal their union; if one party lived on another
plantation, such a master might even intercede for the purchase of the
other party.

On other plantations, though, the marriage ceremony took the form
of "jumping over the broom." This was performed after work hours in
some cabin. In the presence of a few slaves a boom was placed on the
bride would leap across the broom, then the groom, and so they were
married.

Religious teaching was often permitted; perhaps the Spanish in-
fluence was responsible for this. Even after emancipation of the slaves
there were no churches for Negroes in St. Augustine but Negro Catholic once,
and protestant Negro missionaries were beaten by Negro Catholics when
they attempted to establish Baptist and Methodist churches. Throughout
Florida there was a suspicion that protestant missionaries were aboli-
tionists. Some slaves were forbidden to attend church meetings. At
the hamlet of Sixteen, Florida, one slave woman saw her son killed for
attending church, and was threaened with death herself if she did not
cease weeping over the incident.

The white churches which allowed slaves to attend required that
they enter by a separate door, and sit in a section reserved for them.
Some churches held special services designed for slaves after the reg-
ular sermons.

By 1856, however, only a few owners refused to permit their slaves
to listen to service in either the white churches or colored meetings;
attendance at religious services had come to be considered an indis-
pensable activity of slaves on most Florida plantations. Reasons for
this change appear to have been--from the standpoint of slave-owners--
largely economic. Preachers, whether white or Negro, generally based
their exortations on the theme: "Love your master. Don't steal. Be
obedient." In return, slaves were assured that they would be rewarded
with heavenly bliss after death; if they deviated from the code, they
could expect nothing better than the fires of hell. The inference was
also made that disobedient slaves would experience a more familiar form
of damnation while they lived.

Baptismal services were held at or near the larger plantations.
After several weeks had been spent prepring the slaves for "acceptance
of Christ," a large enough group would be ready to hold a "Christnin."
Robed in a single dress-like garment of white, the candidates, men and
women, would be taken to some nearby stream. There the preacher would
go through an elaborate ceremony, accompanied by the singing and "fall-
ing out" of the witnesing slaves. "Falling out" the other slave would
continue their singing and shouting. A triumphal march back to the
water. These ceremonies take place today in many rural communities.

Some plantations permitted regular Sunday school classes, some-
times taught by kindly young daughters of the masters or by house
slaves who could read. Other owners made attendance at the Sunday
meetings compulsory. One slave complains that "after we had worked in
de fields fun half-pas four ta half-pas six ever day in de week, we'd
have ta git up at sebm o'clock on Sunday an listen to d preacher."
At least one plantation is known to have used a full-time preacher, who
wasn't too well-liked "cause he went roun dressed up in a high hat all
de time, watchin us an meddlin and tellin de master everthing we done.

Beliefs, Superstitions, Cures. The constant efforts of the
preachers to center the slaves' thoughts on the hereafter did not stop
them from having an elaborate system of sgns, beliefs, and cures for
their multitudinous earthly troubles. Many of their remedies for ill-
ness, like ipecac, were no doubt efficacious, though their potency was
usually given a supernatural rather than a natural explanation.

A reported aid to escape was the mixture of "graveyard dust an
lightwood splinters that my Uncle Bob an Uncle July smeared on their
feet when they run away, an Bob Amos' hounds coulden break the spell
an ketch em." While they were hiding in the woods, cotton seed sprin-
kled on the ground kept them from getting cold.

Hogs, according to the belief of the slaves, could see the wind
with ease and it was always blood-red to them. Early on every Christ-
mas morning all animal were believed to talk fluently. The rind of
a watermelon worn around the neck would eliminate all trouble for a
child in teething, and if melons were not in season, a pearl button
would accomplish the same result. A concoction of boiled wasps' nests
and vinegar would aid the child who was slow in learning to walk. Occa-
sional nursing at the breast by a child of two, three, or more years
would save it from trouble with its teeth and bones. Sheep droppings
made an excellent remedy, used either as a liniment or a medicine and
the ipecac plant was a great favorite for any ailment of stomach or
respiratory tract.

Slave Education. Education for slaves was almost entirely voca-
tional that is, they were trained in order to increase their efficiency
and value to their owner. On some plantations reading and writing was
permited, and on at least one, Kingsley's, it was part of the intelli-
gent slave's training. In Leon County one master's daughter spent each
Sunday teaching the slaves to read and write. On a plantation near
Pensacola, slaves caught attempting to write had their finger cut off.

Eugenics to Order. The rapid breeding of slaves, to replace
deaths and for purposes of sale and trade, was desired on most planta-
tions. Thus there were women whose chief function was that of
"breeder," and whose daily chores were confined to light work around
the house. Their job was to have big healthy children, and they were
mated with the most promising of the men. It was not unusual for the
breeder to bear twelve of fourteen children during her active life.

Some of the Negro women were mated with their white master or
overseer; this resulted in the much sought-after mulattoes, used as
house slaves. They were thought to be less strong than other Negroes,
and care was used in working them.

Another plantation job was that of "suckler." Her duty was to
nurse the babies while their mothers were at work in the fields.
Still others tended the young children. Many women did not leave their
work in the fields until their labor pains started, and their babies
were given to sucklers when only a few weeks old.

Treatment of Florida Slaves. Conditions under which Florida slaves
lived varied greatly. From the kindnesses of the Kingsleys, Sandersons,
and Blounts--all of whom were known to discharge brutal overseers--
treatment went to other extreme as on the Lopez plantation near St.
Augustine, where ex-slaves say they were beaten for hours at a time by
the master himself.

There seem to have been few really "hard" plantations in
Florida than in other states where there were more and larger planta-
tions. Some owners, like the Sandersons and Reids in Duval County ,
and the Hansons in St. Johns , carefully avoided separating families
when buying or selling slaves; others almost never sold a slave, and
refused to employ overseers who beat slaves. One slave remembers
that he was never forced to do any strenuous work as long as he beat
the slaves of the other masters at marbles; another was permitted to earn
extra money by distilling moonshine. Several recall having been per-
mitted to plant small gardens for themselves near their cabins.

That some of these kind masters may have been known to the slaves
is evident in the fact that there are several instances of Negroes who
voluntarily entered slavery in order to secure the freedom of others.
One such instance occurred on the Cone plantation in Columbia County ;
another three years period of voluntary slavery was entered nto in the
vicinity of St. Augustine . In this case the sum of $850 had to be paid
in work. In Columbia County , Cato Smith, a free Connecticut Negro
traveling in Florida out of curiosity, entered into a 7-year period
of slavery in order to free the woman he wanted to marry. He was for-
tunate and within four years he had his wife, as well as a small in-
come from his labor.

Slaves reacted differently to cruel masters; some were thoroughly
broken in spirit, while others resorted to retaliation, not always
open, but smetimes quite effective. One woman, tiring of the beat-
ings given her by an overseer, hacked him to death with a hoe; anoth-
or killed the Negro overseer on her master's plantation when he goaded
her too far, then went to her master and bade him punish her as he saw
fit. She says that he sent her to a cabin by herself and told her to
"keep your mouth shut and only do whatever work your mistess has for
you to do and behave yourself."

Escapes. Due to the friendliness of the Seminole Indians and the
relative inexperience of Florida slave owners in practices of slavery,
the number of Negroes who escaped or attempted escape was still high
as late as 1835-40; after that time many plantations employed the
"buck-and-gag" treatment for runaway slaves, a punishment wherein the
slave was doubled about a hoe, shovel or board, tied, and left to lie
in the hot sun. The "bell-and-stocks" system, where an iron halter
was placed around the waist and neck of the slave and a loud bell
attached to it, was another popular method of punishment. And of
course recalcitrant slaves could always be sold to other masters.

Some masters dealt summarily with slaves who attempted to escape;
others regarded the desire to seek liberation as natural, and even
forbade the patrollers to punish their escaped slaves before or upon
returning them. One slave escaped three times as a boy, returned vol-
untarily twice, and when his master went to war he remained on the
plantation as the most dutiful servant of his mistress. Another
escaped slave was captured, severely beaten, and buried alive; other
slaves exhumed him, revived him, and sent him on his way again. Nor
was he recaptured.

The use of bloodhounds is recorded as early as 1837, when several
were imported from Cuba and loosened in the St. Johns River area to
regain a number of Indians who had escaped into the country occupied
jointly by the Seminole and free Negroes. On that occasion the blood-
hounds did not succeed in locating a single refugee.

Some escapes were dramatic. One slave was pursued by bloodhounds,
and when tracked to his hiding place in a creak, one by one the bodies
of the hounds who entered the water after him came floating to the
surface. He was not captured.

Despite the fact that escapes were blamed on whatever free Negroes
could be found in a section, many escapes were aided or engineered by
white people who were either abolition-minded or desired slaves
for purposes of traffic.

Slave Raiders. Slave raiders were other "fleas on the body" of the
institution of slavery. Florida Clayton, daughter of a white father and
a free Negro mother, relates that a large covered wagon used to appear
periodically in her section near Tallahassee. The slave raiders would
remain for several weeks, rounding up with hounds unfortunate escaped
slaves, and often even kidnapping slaves from plantations. The cap-
tured slaves were bound, imprisoned in the wagon, and eventually car-
ried army. Florida recalls the names of "Mister Nimrod" and "Mister
Sheehee" as leaders of the enterprise. She believes the slaves were
taken to Alabama and sold.

Petrollers. The petrollers were not usually slave raiders.
Their duties were the return of slaves to their masters, and they
were particularly active after the War between the States took many
masters away from their plantations.

The fear in which the petrollers were held was due to the fact
that they administered beatings to captured slaves before returning
them to their owners. This was the most dread factor the escaping
slave had to take into consideration.

Self-appointed patrollers were not uncommon: sometimes they were
thrill-seeking young hoodlums who saw in the patrol idea an opportunity
to catch and beat unfortunate Negro runaways, and at the same time re-
ceive a considerable profit.

"Parson" Andrews, a Negro nearing his hundredth birthday and full
of reminiscences about early days in Florida, describes the attempt of
the patrollers to round up a group of slaves and return them to their
plantations. The slaves, he says, were on their way back to their
cabins anyway, but had stopped at the home of another slave for a brief
visit. As they started to leave several of the dread patrollers burst
in. One of the slaves reached into a pile of hot ashes, and threw
them into the faces of the patrollers. In the resulting confusion all
the slaves escaped and returned to their cabins.

Abolitioists. In Leon County near the Campbell plantation, there
were several abolitionists who assisted many of the slaves of the vicin-
ity to gain freedom. And in Jefferson and Madison counties, surrounding
the Panell and Lenton plantations, there were poorer slave owners who
assisted in the escape of slaves from the larger plantations, and then
sold the escaped slaves to itinerant slave traders who came through the
section around the first of the year.

Among the abolitionaist the case of the Hanson brothers in St.
Augustine is interesting. Both brothers came to Florida during the
early days of the Seminole War to fight Indians. One of them returned
to his native New England, thoroughly convinced of the iniquity of the
institution of human bondage; the other remained in the state and estab-
lished a large slave plantation about three miles southwest of St. Augu-
stine. Slaves escaped from one Hanson to be aided in reaching Canada
by the other.
